title: Interdisciplinary Mathematical Modeling for Sustainable Urban Development

context.prior_knowledge: Basic statistics, linear algebra, calculus, and fundamental urban planning concepts
context.additional_context: Project-based learning utilizing mobile apps and online collaboration tools in a BYOD (Bring Your Own Device) environment.

learning_goals: Learners develop a mathematical model quantifying energy consumption and carbon emissions of urban infrastructure systems (e.g., transportation networks, building energy management systems) within three weeks, apply real-world data (e.g., Seoul open data) to achieve over 80% model accuracy, and submit a results report
Learners can design optimization problems reflecting three or more sustainability indicators (social/environmental/economic).
Learners can perform resource allocation simulations using real urban data and write an interpretive report on the results.

Learners collaborate in interdisciplinary teams (3–5 members: developers, designers, planners, etc.) to develop an integrated software solution prototype (implementing ≥3 features) using Agile methods within two weeks, create a 10-minute presentation (10 slides + 3-minute demo video), and submit it at the final presentation session

resources: Mobile-Compatible Data Visualization Tool (Tableau Public, RAWGraphs)
Open-Source Urban Data Platform (UN SDG, World Bank Open Data)

difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
